Tessa Han
AboutResearch

Publications

  • Which Explanation Should I Choose? A Function Approximation Perspective to Characterizing Post Hoc Explanations
    Tessa Han, Suraj Srinivas, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2022
    synopsis What are the basic properties of post hoc explanation methods and when is each method effective? Here, we 1) formalize the local function approximation framework, unifying eight diverse, popular explanation methods; 2) demonstrate that no method can perform optimally in every situation via the no free lunch theorem, calling for a principled approach to selecting among methods; and 3) set forth a guiding principle based on faithful function approximation to guide the selection among existing explanation methods and the design of novel ones. / publication / code
    >> Best Paper Award, ICML Workshop on Interpretable Machine Learning for Healthcare (IMLH), 2022
    >> Oral Spotlight Presentation, ICML IMLH Workshop, 2022

  • The Disagreement Problem in Explainable Machine Learning -- A Practitioner’s Perspective
    Satyapriya Krishna*, Tessa Han*, Alex Gu, Javin Pombra, Shahin Jabbari, Steven Wu, and Hima Lakkaraju (*equal contribution)
    In submission for publication
    synopsis To what extent do explanations from post hoc explanation methods agree and how are disagreeing explanations resolved in practice? Here, we introduce and systematically study the “disagreement problem” in explainable machine learning. We find that existing explanation methods often generate disagreeing explanations and practitioners do not have a principled approach to selecting among disagreeing explanations, resorting to ad hoc heuristics such as personal preference. / publication
    >> Oral Spotlight Presentation, ICML Workshop on Interpretable Machine Learning for Healthcare (IMLH), 2022
    >> Presentation, ACM CHI Workshop on Trust and Reliance in AI-Human Teams (TRAIT), 2022
    >> Featured in Fortune (Article 1 and Article 2)
    >> Featured in Analytics India Magazine (Article)

  • Python and R packages for Interactive Visualization of Spatial Single-Cell Omics Data
    Mark Keller, Trevor Manz, Tessa Han, Ilan Gold, Chuck McCallum, and Nils Gehlenborg
    Conference on Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology and European Conference on Computational Biology (ISMB/ECCB), 2021
    synopsis How do we effectively integrate and visualize high-dimensional, multimodal, spatial data in single-cell genomics? Here, to enable these visualizations, we develop Vitessce (Visual integration tool for exploration of spatial single cell experiments), a web-based, interactive visualization tool. We also develop associated Python, R/RStudio, and RShiny tools to enable using Vitessce within the Python and R bioinformatics ecosystems. / publication
    Tools: Vitessce + code / Python package + code / R package + code / R Shiny + code

  • Genome-Wide Somatic Alterations in Multiple Myeloma Reveal a Superior Outcome Group
    Mehmet Kemal Samur, Anil Aktas Samur, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Raphael Szalat, Tessa Han, Masood Shammas, Paul Richardson, Florence Magrangeas, Stephane Minvielle, Jill Corre, Philippe Moreau, Anjan Thakurta, Kenneth Anderson, Giovanni Parmigiani, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, and Nikhil Munshi
    Journal of Clinical Oncology, 2020
    synopsis What is the genomic landscape of multiple myeloma and what are the genomic markers associated long-term survival? Here, we characterize the genomic landscape of multiple myeloma using deep whole-genome sequencing data. We find mutational signatures that reveal mechanisms of progression and variability in mutational load among known subgroups. In addition, we identify a new, genomically-defined subgroup (characterized by lower mutational load, age-related mutations, and the NRAS mutation) with prolonged overall and progression-free survival. / publication

  • Dysregulated miRNAs after Uniform Treatment Predict Outcome of Newly-Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
    Tessa Han, Stephane Minvielle, Anil Aktas Samur, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Florence Magrangeas, Paul Richardson, Philippe Moreau, Michel Attal, Kenneth Anderson, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, Giovanni Parmigiani, Mehmet Kemal Samur, and Nikhil Munshi
    Blood (Supplemental Issue), 2019
    synopsis What is the role of miRNAs in the prognosis and progression of multiple myeloma? Here, we find that dysregulated miRNAs are predictive of disease prognosis in newly-diagnosed multiple myeloma patients and may contribute to disease progression by targeting key multiple myeloma genes (including MAF, BCL2, 14-3-3 and MYEOV). / publication (abstract)
    >> Abstract Achievement Award, American Society of Hematology, 2019

  • The Landscape of Genome Wide Somatic Alterations Identifies a Good-Risk Group in Newly-Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
    Mehmet Kemal Samur, Anil Aktas Samur, Tessa Han, Marco Roncador, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Raphael Szalat, Masood Shammas, Jill Corre, Paul Richardson, Florence Magrangeas, Stephane Minvielle, Philippe Moreau, Michel Attal, Anjan Thakurta, Kenneth Anderson, Giovanni Parmigiani, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, and Nikhil Munshi
    Blood (Supplemental Issue), 2019
    synopsis At the genomic level, what distinguishes low-risk (long-survival) multiple myeloma patients from high-risk (short-survival) multiple myeloma patients? Here, we analyze whole-genome and whole-transcriptome sequencing data from multiple myeloma patients and identify a new low-risk subgroup in which chromosome and telomere maintenance pathways and genes associated with low bone disease are upregulated, processes associated with DNA damage are downregulated, and there are lower mutation rates for known oncogenes and tumor suppressors (e.g. TP53, CSMD1, and FAT3/FAT4). / publication (abstract)

Thesis

  • Applying Mediation Analysis to Predict Feed Forward Loops as Gene Regulatory Networks in Multiple Myeloma – A Novel Statistical Approach
    Honors thesis for a joint A.B. degree in Statistics and Molecular and Cellular Biology
    Supervisor: Prof. Giovanni Parmigiani (Harvard University)
    >> Hoopes Prize for “outstanding scholarly work or research”, Harvard University, 2020
